abstracts.cdata!:
The Bangladesh Health and Population
            Program Project outcome is unsatisfactory; sustainability
            likely, institutional development impact substantial,
            overall Bank and Borrower performances satisfactory. The
            program offers insight into a number of important design and
            implementation issues with implications for other projects:
            Amongst the key lessons regarding SWAps, these lessons were
            cited: 1) SWAps can be gradually adopted, yielding
            increasing improvements in sector management even when the
            change is incomplete. 2) Mechanisms to facilitate
            implementation when the government has insufficient capacity
            or deficiencies yield good results and allow the government
            to gradually take on the responsibility. 3) Establish
            performance indicators and progress benchmarks for
            establishing the SWAps.    SWAps need to clearly define the
            scope of the "sector" to be managed so that key
            sector stakeholders are reached by program interventions and
            donors. Parallel funding should be discouraged. 5) Donor
            coordination requires negotiating skills, leadership, and
            presence in the field. A Code of Conduct with clear rules of
            engagement for coordinating and managing SWAps needs to be
            defined upfront, to ensure decisions are taken swiftly and
            program focus is maintained. Some lessons about managing
            institutional development included: 1) Not carrying out an
            analysis of the political economy of reforms can lead to
            failure. identify opposition whether within the health
            ministry, physician's associations, other worker's
            associations, or users of the services themselves. 2)
            Identify incentives for stakeholders to bolster
            institutional change. General lessons included: Take into
            account those too poor to consume government services;
            icharging them informal fees is too costly. Participatory
            preparation, while enhancing ownership, can dilute the focus
            of a project's design; strike a balance to ensure both
            goals are met.  Measure not just long-term outcomes but also
            intermediate indicators that would lead to those outcomes in
            order to ensure program effects can be measured. Set targets
            related to the capacity of the implementing entity. A risk
            management strategy must be an essential part of annual
            program reviews and routine project supervision.
